rename.from: Exactly, I wonder if Bevy should actually prohibit `eprintln` and `println` since we always have access to `log` and/or `tracing`...
rename.to: Bevy should prohibit `eprintln` and `println` and prefer `log` and/or `tracing`

body: there are some places, mostly parts of bevy_ecs, app initialization or in tests, where we can't assume a logger has been setup. well, and logger setup itself ðŸ˜„

> there are some places, mostly parts of bevy_ecs, app initialization or in tests, where we can't assume a logger has been setup. well, and logger setup itself ðŸ˜„ 

Since this should be the exception rather than the rule, perhaps we could `deny` `e/println!`, and then explicitly `expect` its usage in the (hopefully small) number of places it's required?

Yup!
println is a big enough trap that it's probably worth it, but it's not as simple as forbid and replace all

rename.from: Bevy should prohibit `eprintln` and `println` and prefer `log` and/or `tracing`
rename.to: Bevy should deny `eprintln` and `println` and prefer `log` and/or `tracing`

body: Can you deny macros in deny.toml? If you can, I think you can `expect` the lint in the exceptional places.

It looks like there's a provided lint, [`print_stdout`](https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#/print_stdout) that can be used for this, so we don't even need to deny the methods (which as @BenjaminBrienen points out might not be possible since these are macros). I'll need to test to see if it also applies to `eprintln` too.

> I'll need to test to see if it also applies to `eprintln` too.

Probably not as there's a [`print_stderr`](https://rust-lang.github.io/rust-clippy/master/index.html#print_stderr) lint
`no_std` does not have `e/println` so it will need to be done at some point

issue.title: Add `print_stdout` and `print_stderr` lints (#17446)

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
# Objective

- Prevent usage of `println!`, `eprintln!` and the like because they require `std`
- Fixes #17446

## Solution

- Enable the `print_stdout` and `print_stderr` clippy lints
- Replace all `println!` and `eprintln!` occurrences with `log::*` where applicable or alternatively ignore the warnings

## Testing

- Run `cargo clippy --workspace` to ensure that there are no warnings relating to printing to `stdout` or `stderr`
